title: Quiz 5: High-Risk Neonate Management
topicName: Unit Three Part One: Labour and Puerperium
description: Preterm infants, respiratory distress syndrome, and high-risk neonatal conditions

questions.question: What is the definition of a preterm infant?
questions.explanation: A preterm infant is defined as one born before 37 completed weeks of gestation. Preterm infants are at increased risk for various complications including respiratory distress, hypothermia, and infection.
questions.hint: The cutoff for full-term is 37 weeks.

questions.question: What is the primary cause of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) in newborns?
questions.explanation: Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) is primarily caused by surfactant deficiency, which is most common in preterm infants. Surfactant reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents collapse.
questions.hint: This substance helps keep the alveoli open.

questions.question: Surfactant replacement therapy is the treatment of choice for severe RDS.
questions.explanation: True. Surfactant replacement therapy is the treatment of choice for severe RDS. It is administered directly into the trachea and helps improve lung compliance and oxygenation by reducing alveolar surface tension.
questions.hint: This treatment replaces what the preterm infant lacks.

questions.question: Which of the following are risk factors for preterm birth? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Risk factors for preterm birth include multiple gestation, maternal hypertension (preeclampsia), infection (chorioamnionitis, urinary tract infections), and previous preterm birth. Advanced maternal age is not a major risk factor.
questions.hint: Focus on conditions that can trigger early labor.

questions.question: Match each birth weight classification with its definition:
questions.explanation: LBW = less than 2500 grams, VLBW = less than 1500 grams, ELBW = less than 1000 grams. These classifications help identify infants at highest risk for complications.
questions.hint: The lower the weight, the higher the risk category.

questions.question: Neonatal hypoglycemia is typically defined as blood glucose below ___BLANK___ mmol/L.
questions.explanation: Neonatal hypoglycemia is generally defined as blood glucose below 2.6 mmol/L (47 mg/dL). It can cause neurological damage if not promptly recognized and treated with glucose administration.
questions.hint: This threshold is used internationally for diagnosis.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of neonatal seizures?
questions.explanation: Hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is the most common cause of neonatal seizures. It results from perinatal asphyxia and can lead to significant neurological impairment including cerebral palsy and developmental delay.
questions.hint: This condition results from lack of oxygen to the brain.

questions.question: What is the primary complication of meconium aspiration syndrome?

options.text: Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN)

questions.explanation: The primary complication of meconium aspiration syndrome is persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN), which occurs when meconium causes severe lung inflammation and pulmonary vasoconstriction.
questions.hint: This complication affects the pulmonary circulation.

questions.question: Kernicterus is a complication of untreated severe hyperbilirubinemia.
questions.explanation: True. Kernicterus is a neurological syndrome caused by bilirubin deposition in the brain due to untreated severe hyperbilirubinemia. It can result in permanent neurological damage including hearing loss, cerebral palsy, and intellectual disability.
questions.hint: This condition involves bilirubin affecting the brain.

questions.question: What is the treatment for severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.explanation: Phototherapy is the treatment of choice for severe neonatal hyperbilirubinemia. It converts bilirubin to water-soluble forms that can be excreted. Exchange transfusion may be required for extreme cases unresponsive to phototherapy.
questions.hint: This treatment uses light to break down bilirubin.
